summary: alpha-, beta-, and gamma-coronavirus are classified into three well-accepted genera. deltacoronavirus is proposed as an additional group in the family. gammacoronaviruses, represented by the infectious bronchitis virus, are detected primarily in birds including poultry. the wild birds are important reservoirs for avian influenza A virus [13], and may be for other respiratory and enteric viruses. in recent years, ACoVs have been isolated from various wild bird species that create a suspicion that wild birds play a role as CoV reservoirs and as ACoV carrier influencing its epidemiology. screening and downstream characterization and evolutionary analysis confirm the circulation of ACoVs in wild birds. understanding dynamics and richness of wilds birds in carrying avian pathogens will be steppingstone in devising any disease control and eradication campaign in the country. dakahlia Kafr El Sheikh Gharbia Qalubia Menofia Giza Benisuef Total C. coturnix 23 21 20 22 23 92% 92% 92% 92% 92% 92% 92% 92% 92% 92% polymerase (RdRp) and Spike (S1) genes Amplification and Sequencing Viral RNA was extracted from the allantoic fluids using the Trizol LS® reagent kit. the eluted RNA in 30 L of nuclease free water was stored at (70 °C) until processing for the amplification. analysis of full length S1 protein was carried out using bioEdit software version 7.0.4.1 [23]. the dataset was aligned in BioEdit version 7.0.1 [23] using Clustal W algorithm. a best-fit model was chosen on which further calculations were based. a total of five hundred- fifty-seven (n = 557) cloacal/fecal swabs were collected from randomly-selected wild birds-dense and ACoV-endemic areas in eight Egyptian provinces during the year of 2016. samples were blindly propagated for three passages in the allantoic sac of 9 day-old specific pathogen free (SPF) embryonated chicken eggs by standard procedures. ibis 7 150 4.7 Pelecaniformes Ardeidae Bubulcus B. ibis 4 131 3.1 Total = 4 4 4 N-linked glycosylation sites in most of the Egyptian ACoV strains were found. nine NXT and eight NXS sites were found in all the 14 isolates reported in this study. compared hypervariable regions that five isolates (MF034379.1 ACoV/quail/Sharqia-Egypt/VRLCU-8/2016,MF034380.1 ACoV/cattle t/VRLCU-10/2016, MF034382.1 ACoV/teal/Benisuef-Egypt/VRLCU-11/2016 and MF034383.1 ACoV/cattle egret/Kafr El phylogenetically subclassified into subgroups/subclusters (Figure 4) based on ACoVs emergence, origin, and evolution. the detected viruses in this study belonged to gamma-coronaviruses. trees likelihood method. recombinant strain MF034381.1 ACoV/cattle egret/Kafr El Sheikh-Egypt/VRLCU-10/2016. recombinant strain MF034381.1 ACoV/teal/Kafr El Sheikh-Egypt/VRLCU-13/2016. the amino acids of the S1 subunit have three HVRs, located within amino acids 38–67, 91–141, and 274–387 [3,4,5] and these HVRs were considered an essential determinant of coronavirus serotype specificity. evidence that wild birds might constitute transmission vectors for ACoVs even in a huge geographic territory. the number of samples analyzed in this study was limited. it can be assumed that the genetic variation of ACoVs among wild birds is much higher than previously thought. most of ACoVs available on GenBank are divided into variant and classic groups. the majority of the Egyptian ACoV strains belong to QX-like, 4/91, IS/1494/06 (Egy/Variant-1) and IS/885 (Egy/Variant-2) genotypes. emergence of Egy/variant 1 (IS/1494/06-like) and Egy/variant 2 (IS/885-like) in Egypt has been introduced to the poultry population raises several speculations. recombination events in the ACoV genome play a major role in the origin and adaptation of the virus. many recombination events have been reported in different ACoV strains, not only between field (wild-type) and vaccine viruses but also among field viruses within the same genotype (intra-genotypic) or between different genotypes (inter-genotypic) [41,40], giving rise to new ACoV genotypes. positively selected fragments of genes encoding viral proteins have been documented in other viruses. there is an association between positively selected sites along the S1 subunit identified in this study and mapped neutralizing epitopes. full genome sequencing will provide detailed information on different subgroups. this would require comprehensive data through better surveillance of wild birds.
